acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 of 150 mg/kg (HSDB, 2003), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 of 42 mg/kg (EHC 224, 2001), the substance was classified into Category 2.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Since arsenic and arsenic compounds are rated as carcinogenic to humans according to IARC Suppl. 7 (1987), ACGIH-TLV (2008), and MAK/BAT (2007), the substances were classified into Category 1A.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: According to EHC 224 (2001) and Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO (2008)), induction of micronuclei and chromosomal aberrations were observed in several in vivo tests using mouse bone marrow. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2. As additional background information, the dominant lethal test using mice was negative (EHC 224 (2001), Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO) (2008)).

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Given its substance-specific UN No. 2027, the substance is rated as Divisiion 6.1, II; not Division 5.1, by the UNRTDG. Despite this information, due to lack of additional data, classification is not possible.

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
In a 3-generation study in mice given this substance in drinking water, there was a trend toward a decrease number of pups per litter in all three generations of the treated group (ATSDR, 2007). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2.
According to EHC 224 (2001), which is a List 1 information source, description for arsenic and arsenic compounds suggested toxic effects of the substance on reproduction in humans; in addition, fetal toxicity and teratogenic effects were seen at doses that produce maternal toxicity in animal tests. Based on this information, the substance was classified into Category 2. Catalog of Teratogenic Agents (2004), which is equivalent to List 1 sources, supports the conclusion that inorganic arsenic is not teratogenic to humans.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Since inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to irritate human eyes (HSG 70, 1992; PIM 042, 1996), this substance was classified into Category 2.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to cause irritation (DFGOT vol. 21, 2005). However, since no further information is available, classification is not possible.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: A guinea pig maximization test gave negative results (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO) (2008); EHC 224 (2001)). In human tests, both positive (DFGOT Vol. 21, 2005) and negative results (EHC 224 (2001)) are reported. As such, classification is not possible.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: It is stable in contact with water. (According to Merck (13th, 2001) and Sax (11th, 2004), it is readily soluble in water.)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In a 2-year mixed diet study using rats, the effect of the substance on the bile duct was noted at the dose of 12 mg/kg bw (DFGOT Vol. 21 (2002)). Thus, the substance falls under Category 2 (digestive system). In a mixed diet study using dogs, no serious symptoms were noted (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO) (2008); DFGOT Vol. 21 (2002)); however, the dose given was 8 mg/kg bw/day, which was below the guidance dose value. According to EHC 224 (2001) on arsenic and its inorganic compounds in relation to humans, gastrointestinal tract disorder; nervous disorder; effects on the blood system; and abnormalities in cardiovascular system, kidney, and liver were observed. Thus, target organs for these substances are the gastrointestinal tract, heart, brain, and kidney. In addition, the skin, bone marrow and peripheral nervous system are also affected by this substance. Moreover, according to ACGIH (2001), the upper respiratory tract and lung are also affected. Based on these reports, this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, and skin).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: No test results were found on single exposure to this substance other than lethal effects. In humans, the following acute toxic effects by arsenic compounds are documented: symptoms of the gastrointestinal tract, cardiovascular system, nerves, and blood system; conjunctivitis and dermatitis as well as irritation to the nasal mucosa, pharynx, and trachea; frequent urination or anuria due to a blockage of renal tubules with clots of hemoglobin (IARC 23 (1980)); depression of bone marrow functions; and hepatomegaly (EHC 224 (2001)). In accordance with these reports, the digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver were considered to be target organs, and this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver).
